text: uh
hi everyone america is crumbling as a
society here the internet's busiest
music nerd i hope you're doing well it's
time for a review of this new kralis
album psychog experimental and extreme
metal outfit kralis they are back with a
brand new lp believe it or not their
second of 2022. the record crystalline
exhaustion that i loved earlier this
year apparently was uh tracked and
recorded toward the finish of 2021 this
new one over here was put together back
in may which is a pretty short amount of
time between records even for a band as
historically prolific as krallus but i
assume this may come down to a
willingness to get back into the swing
of things since like many artists out
there kovit did kind of
slow down the band's output the one
pandemic record that they did come out
with wasn't necessarily their best due
to the unique conditions under which it
was recorded still crystalline
exhaustions returned to a true black
metal form with an increase in synth
work made in my opinion one of kralis's
best records so far so i was kind of
curious to see if psychogear would be
a continuation of what we heard on that
lp a new direction of some sort now this
project is not a lengthy one at 37
minutes or so and this lp also sees the
band once again
building their records not out of
shorter pieces compiling into a
full-length record but just kind of a
handful of longer ones ranging from 7 to
13 minutes and the styles and aesthetics
brought out on each track are a bit of a
mixed bag there's the title track the
intro which is maybe my least favorite
which is a thunderous and relentless mix
of black metal death metal and
progressive metal nothing too
groundbreaking for the band
stylistically which isn't inherently bad
especially given all the thrilling rift
passages in the first half i could kind
of do without the metallic twinkling
synth leads though but where the song
ultimately loses me is in the second
half with all these winding reverb
guitar arpeggio passages which lose
direction pretty fast yes there is some
very muscular drum work going on in
these sections but this whole portion
seems to be just kind of building up
this endless sense of tension that that
never truly gets resolved i get a lot
more out of the track deliberate fog
which has a much smudgier mix by
comparison but i suppose it does make
sense as this is a track in more of an
atmospheric black metal style and i
actually think this is one of the better
tracks kralis has put out in this lane
in a minute it's a nine-minute monster
and the consistent blast beats driving
bass guitar arpeggios and haunting
synthesizers make for a pretty
mesmerizing listen the whole thing
gradually mellows out into these more
spacious sections around the middle
which are pretty gratifying as well but
the build toward the end is really the
best part it somehow sounds heavier and
more enveloping than anything that went
on in the first leg the track overall
feels like i'm kind of traveling very
quickly through some kind of [ __ ]
interdimensional portal the third track
on this thing is of even more epic
proportions with what sounds like a
full-on orchestral intro like some real
game of thrones [ __ ] with the war drums
and the eerie harmonies and the grand
arrangements now given the credits of
the record all these sounds are most
likely synthesized or put together in a
daw in some way but they still sound
sick and they also seamlessly transition
into these truly hellish classic black
metal style blast beats and tremolo
guitars even a chilly little dungeon
synth layer hanging there in the mix the
whole thing sounds like it's straight
out of the 90s scene in norway with old
school black metal
wretches and all but now on this cralles
record executed with a gargantuan sound
and the type of tightness speed and
virtuosity that you could only expect
from a band at krallus's talent level
it's fantastically executed but also
incredibly raw now this is also the
longest track on the lp by several
minutes but the band more than justifies
this runtime with lots of changes lots
of various passages and while there is a
lot of shifting and evolution going on
each section of the track remains
focused none of the progressions or
changes feel disjointed or awkward and
the wintry guitar and synth passages
toward the end are a nice mellow finish
for the cut too then we have an
aggressive closer for the lp that sends
the whole thing out with a bang the
dizzying prague guitar riffs and leads
make a return that moves on to some very
discordant chord progressions that are
backed up with really really powerful
pounding drumming weinstein is just like
going absolutely mad on the skins and
this cut undergoes quite a progression
too getting more gloomy with chilling
synth layers filling the air and
eventually finishing off with these
really weepy string section layers which
make for one of the more dramatic
finishes of any kralis album so far but
yeah overall even though this was not
one of the band's most cohesive records
aesthetically sonically and it's not one
of their most robust records lengthwise
i still thought this was a pretty solid
one from kralis cool to hear the band
continuing to vary their sound up
experiment here and there with adding
more layers presenting mixes and
instrumental passages that are heavier
thicker more dense more ambitious as
someone who's been following kralis's
work for a while now it would be
fantastic to hear the band continue on
this path where they are experimenting
with these grand and very large
instrumental palettes and maybe bring
that onto a record that has a bit more
flow a bit more follow-through a bit
more of a macro picture as what it's
going to be thematically or sonically
feeling a decent two-strong seven on
this one tran position have you given
this record a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head is another video that you can
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel anthony fantano
kralis
forever
